title: Genereate a unique id for each compilation and use the id as key for map rather than reference
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**
Current behavior: `NormalModule.getCompilationHooks` is using a map whose key is the reference of compilation.
expected behavior: give each compilation a unique id, and use the id as the key of the map to find hooks.

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
For myself, I am developing a successor of speed-measure-webpack-plugin to measure the time of each loader and plugin, to do this, I use Proxy(like speed-measure-webpack-plugin) to warp loader and tap method so that I could run extra logic before and after each loader and hook is really executed.
However, to proxy tap method, I need to proxy everything between compiler and the tap, including the compilation.
But if webpack is using reference-equal for some map, because the proxied compilation and the real compilation is different, there is some strange error.

There might be some other ways to do the trick, but it will be pretty good if webpack is able to make this small change.

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**

When each compilation is created, generate a uuid as ID. Then use the ID as the key of the internal map inside `NormalModule.getCompilationHooks` to get hooks.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
yes
author: ShuiRuTian

comments.body: In theory you can do the same on the plugin side, I am not agains it, but just want to verify we can't solve it on the plugin side
Sure, let me dig into code and have some more investigation....

I found that we could hack `WeakMap` to try to use a custom ID. So we do not need to change webpack itself. This approach works fine for now.

Thanks!

title: Should contentHash happen before the moduleIds process?
body:
## Feature request

I notice our static dependency file's hash will be changed sometimes. After my investigation it's caused by different `moduleIds`.
I take an experiment to prove it. 
First, I saved my project in two version while their `monaco-editor` versions are identity. When I used the `moduleIds: 'named'` and built my  project in prod env. They got the same content hash. 
But when I changed the `modulesIds` to an Id type, e.g. 'deterministic', 'size'. They got different hash values. 
I did not have idea for why it happened since it was hard to read in prod env. But I think it was caused by importing different modules.
However, the dependencies's content are identity. So I expect the content hash will be identity.


**What is the expected behavior?**
Hash content should not be disturbed by `moduleIds`.

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
To avoid the content hash being disturbed by moduleIds

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**
Hash content before moduleIds optimization will avoid this issue.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
no
author: adamma1024

comments.body: How many chunks you have? Do you extract runtime? If you have dymanic chunks their names are changed so contenthash is different. Maybe you can provide small example?

> How many chunks you have? Do you extract runtime? If you have dymanic chunks their names are changed so contenthash is different. Maybe you can provide small example?

Thanks for your reply. I found this issue on `monaco-editor` package. It's a third part package, I never change its codes. And I don't know if it used the dymanic chunks within. 
Do you mean the `moduleIds` differences are caused by dymanic chunks? Sure, it could have some additional dymanic chunks in our new codes. And it would cause the `moduleIds` difference indeed.
But I think it should not become a factor to change a file's contenthash which is never been changed, right?
So my question is "Should the contenthash be influenced by moduleIds?" That's the thing I feel weird. 
From my perspective, the calculating `contenthash` process should be earlier than calculating `moduleIds` to ensure the content hash is only influenced by content, not others.

Btw, what's the rule for calculating the `moduleIds` ? Is there another way to let all of `moduleIds` fixed in the `monaco-editor`. I just know a way is to set `moduleIds: 'named'`. Unfortunately, t will increase the size of the bundle.

> I saved my project in two version while their monaco-editor versions are identity.

what does it means? The important thing is when
```js
import("monaco-editor") /* add a non-initial chunk */
```
happens with same configuration it should have same content hash (if editor was not changed)

if you have something like 1st webpack config with one `moduleIds` ( result in 1st content hash ) and change webpack config to another `moduleIds` => this will change content hash since module ids alaso a part of content..
@adamma1024 Do you have the special plugin for `monaco-editor` (if I remember right there is bug there, it was reported multiple times). Also maybe you can create small reprocible test repo?

> > I saved my project in two version while their monaco-editor versions are identity.
> 
> what does it means? The important thing is when
> 
> ```js
> import("monaco-editor") /* add a non-initial chunk */
> ```
> 
> happens with same configuration it should have same content hash (if editor was not changed)

Yes, indeed, but it will be changed in the following scenario:
Monday, we released our project named `version1`, the release contained a `monaco.1.js`
Tuesday, some guys add new `dynamic`  modules to the project and released the `version2`. Will it still be calculated to `monaco.1.js`? I think it should be. But the fact is as @alexander-akait  said, it probably was `monaco.2.js` since the `module number changed`.
What is its effect of it? It will let our user's browser cache doesn't work. They need to download `monaco.2.js` when we publish our `version2`. The worse thing is it won't just influence one module. I am not sure how many packages will be influenced.
Any time we add new `dynamic` modules it probably happens. That's why I want to report it. It's not friendly and it's weird. Because I never change the `monaco` version. But its content hash probably is changed.

> @adamma1024 Do you have the special plugin for `monaco-editor` (if I remember right there is bug there, it was reported multiple times). Also maybe you can create small reprocible test repo?

I just used `new MonacoWebpackPlugin({ globalAPI: true })`.
I am not sure that I can provide a reproducible test repo. As we all know, the dependency's module id won't be changed at any time. And I have not found a way to repro it.
But I can promise that I will provide it to you as long as I create a reproducible repo.

> if you have something like 1st webpack config with one `moduleIds` ( result in 1st content hash ) and change webpack config to another `moduleIds` => this will change content hash since module ids alaso a part of content..

The webpack's config was never changed. But the module id in Monaco has been changed. Just like:
```
//monaco.js
import A from 'A'
```
After compiled:
```
import A from [1] // 1 is module id
```
If we import a new dynamic module it probably be that:
```
import A from [2] // Since the 1 is taken by the dynamic module.
```
So the content hash will be changed when it happens.

Sounds like a bug in `MonacoWebpackPlugin` (i faced with it some time ago), is it possible to check this bug without this plugin (because we don't have reproducible test repo we should check all possible places)

title: Support exclude rules config for cache.buildDependencies
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**

Exclude some files/directories from the buildDependencies collected by `FileSystemInfo.resolveBuildDependencies()`

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**

Sometimes some loader reads config from `projectRoot/package.json` by `require()` (for example `postcss-load-config -> lilconfig`) in this case `projectRoot/package.json` will be collected as a buildDependency by `FileSystemInfo.resolveBuildDependencies()`, and any change of `projectRoot/package.json` (such as project dependency update) will cause the invalidation of the full filesystem cache.

Actually I have not written any postcss config in my package.json file, so I want a exclude rules config to remove `projectRoot/package.json` from the buildDependencies. 

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**
Support exclude rules config for cache.buildDependencies

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
yes
author: hiyuki

comments.body: I don't think it is right direction to solve a problem, we should invalid cache when you change `package.json`, so it is expected
@hiyuki this behaviour is expected, since this `package.json` is a build dependency

But in this case I know I have no postcss config in the `package.json`, but in the `postcss.config.js`, because of `lilconfig` trying to `require` both of them, the `package.json` has been regarded as a build dependency, actually the change of `package.json` has no side effect to the webpack compilation.
for webpack it is impossible to determine this, so it adds all to build dependencies.

> for webpack it is impossible to determine this, so it adds all to build dependencies.

Yes I know so I want a config to customize the build dependencies.
You can't do it

Ok, actually I can pass a load config to `lilconfig` to read `package.json` by `fs.readFile` instead of `require` to avoid this problem. 
Thanks for your replies. @vankop @alexander-akait

In my case, we have to change the version number of `package.json` when we release the project. This leads to cache invalidation. In fact, the dependent module has not changed.

I agree that the cache should be cleared when dependency changes. It would be better to provide some options for more precise control.

For example, some options are provided to control the generation of cache 'hash' of some files?
@starmooms not all cache invalidates in your case
But, it will take more than `30s` to re resolve build dependencies...

Upvoting the request a lot. Have a similar build, we got a shared monorepository with all the common packages in an enterprise build. Build takes about 10 minutes, if cached it can run 30 seconds.

Unfortunately our common packages are all published on each change, even if there aren't changes in one of the packages.
Webpack build is based on `@scope/conf` package, which contains core config shared throughout all of the projects, once `@scope/conf/package.json` version is raised (which is every build), buildDependencies are mismatched and the entire cache invalidated. (Even though the @scope/conf contents aren't actually changed)

Spent a good couple of days trying to hack into `PackFileCacheStrategy` and `FileSystemInfo`, to allow exclusion of package.json in build dependencies with no luck, good job on isolating it :)

Instead I had to copy/paste the cache section of `WebpackOptionsApply` into a custom plugin to monkeyPatch `PackFileCacheStrategy.createSnapshot` into filtering out `package.json` files. That fixed the issue, but the price is a bit too expensive.

It would be nice to have:
- a simple `tapable` before `createSnapshot` method call to insert custom plugin logic (maybe a `tapable` inside `Cache` to return an instance of `the Strategy`?);
- a way to output the list of mismatched buildDependencies paths, so that it's possible to rewrite configuration files avoiding mismatch (possibly another `tapable`, or a publicly available field inside `PackFileCacheStrategy`).
@IMalyugin I am fine to look at PRs

title: Allow to use [contenthash] (of minified JS file) for building the name of an external source map file
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

When storing a source maps in a separate file, it should be possible to use the same filename (despite the file extension) for the source map as is used for the minified JS source file. This does currently not work when the minified source file uses the [contenthash] in its name.

Example:
```
output: {
  chunkFilename: "[name].[contenthash:8].js",
  filename: "[name].[contenthash:8].js"
},
```
produces filenames like `something.5482zd820.js`.

When using `[contenthash:8]` for the filename of the source map, too, a content hash is included in the generated source map file as well, but of course that is the hash for the source map's own content and different from the hash of the minified JS file.

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**

I would like to have something similar to [contenthash] that allows to refer to the minified JS file's content hash rather than the source map file's own hash when building its name, so I can get the following:

```
something.5482zd820.js
something.5482zd820.js.map
```
(both files using the same hash value here)

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**

In my use case I don't know the "public path" upfront. It is determined at runtime. So I don't can't insert a static hint/comment into the minified JS file which directs to browser to the absolute location of the corresponding source map file. Instead, I use the Sourcemap response header when delivering the minified JS files computing the location for the corresponding source map file. This computation (deriving the URL of the source map file form the URL of the minified JS file) is much easier when the source map file has the same filename (despite the extension of coursed) than the minified JS file.

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**


**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
no
author: henning-meinhardt

comments.body: It is wrong usage, name should be same, i.e. for `script.12345678.js` should be `script.12345678.map.js` file
If you need something non standard, we have plugin API and you can do it using API

@alexander-akait thanks. Right, the name should be the same, this is actually what I wanted to archive. Regarding the API, can you give me a hint where to get started (not an experienced webpack contributor)
We already generate the same name, what is the problem?

Just use:
```
output: {
  chunkFilename: "[name].[contenthash:8].js",
  filename: "[name].[contenthash:8].js"
},
```

@alexander-akait I can't see the difference from the output section you posted from the the one i'm using. Using that, I get:
```
file.12345678.js
file.js.map
```
when having the following applied for source map generation:
```
plugins: [
	new webpack.SourceMapDevToolPlugin ({
		// filename: "[name].[contenthash:8].js.map",
		append: false
	})
]
```
When enabling the commented out line, I get the following instead:
```
file.12345678.js
file.57402411.js.map
```
because [contenthash] computes to the hash of the source map file.

title: Allow to replace asset/resource with `new URL(import.meta.url, '...')` when `output.libraryTarget` is 'module'
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**

Currently asset/resource works like this:

```js
import mainImage from './images/main.png';

img.src = mainImage; // '/dist/151cfcfa1bd74779aadb.png'
```

However, this does not work when using webpack to build a library. But luckily, if the `output.libraryTarget` is 'module', we can use `import.meta.url` like this:

```js
import mainImage from './images/main.png';

img.src = mainImage; // new URL(import.meta.url, './151cfcfa1bd74779aadb.png')
```

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**

This make assets work for libraries. The output of the library may not compatible with all bundlers, but at lease it works with the browser's native es module.

Alse see: #2933

title: webpack 4/5 incompatible when dynamic load commonjs module exports promise
body:
# Bug report
two code files:

x.js (maybe a npm commonjs module):

```js
module.exports = new Promise((resolve)=>resolve(1));
```

main.js

```js
import('./x').then(m=>console.log(m))
```

**What is the current behavior?**

webpack4:  console `{default:<Promise>}`

webpack5: console `1`

**What is the expected behavior?**

webpack4 ?
author: yiminghe

comments.body: ~~Expected, it is breaking change between v4 and v5~~ I am wrong, it is bug, sorry

That's working as expected.

A ESM with a `then` export will lead to executing that function on `import()`.
Similar to that a CommonJS module will have a `then` export (from the Promise object) and will lead to execution of that `then` method, which will lead to the promise result.

title: Module Federation runtime-dynamic share scope
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

We're trying to have a very strict setup, where all versions of MFEs get the exact versions of packages they were tested with locally. We're having a few hiccups with peer dependencies - mainly react UI libraries where react is marked as a peer dependency. Two MFEs could have the same version of a react UI library, but different versions of react.

For now, we've got a share scope with a convention to use the name and version of singleton package (i.e. `shareScope: "react@17.0.1"` - as below). However, this won't scale well past more than one singleton package.

I've noticed the code outputs this for container initialization:-

```js
var init = (shareScope, initScope) => {
	if (!__webpack_require__.S) return;
	var oldScope = __webpack_require__.S["react@17.0.1"];
	var name = "react@17.0.1"
	if(oldScope && oldScope !== shareScope) throw new Error("Container initialization failed as it has already been initialized with a different share scope");
	__webpack_require__.S[name] = shareScope;
	return __webpack_require__.I(name, initScope);
};
```

If we changed this to:-

```diff
- var init = (shareScope, initScope) => {
+ var init = (shareScope, initScope, name) => {
+	if (!name) name = "react@17.0.1"
	if (!__webpack_require__.S) return;
-	var oldScope = __webpack_require__.S["react@17.0.1"];
+	var oldScope = __webpack_require__.S[name];
-	var name = "react@17.0.1"
	if(oldScope && oldScope !== shareScope) throw new Error("Container initialization failed as it has already been initialized with a different share scope");
	__webpack_require__.S[name] = shareScope;
	return __webpack_require__.I(name, initScope);
};
```

Then I think we have most of what we need to support this - with this pseudo-code,

```js
const webpackScopes = [];

const loadMFE = async (name, singletonPackages) => {
  let scope = webpackScopes.find((scope) => {
    return singletonPackagesAreCompatible(
      singletonPackages,
      scope.singletonPackages
    );
  });

  if (!scope) {
    scope = { name, singletonPackages };
    await __webpack_init_sharing__(scope.name);
    webpackScopes.push(scope);
  } else {
    updateScopeWithNewSingletonPackages(scope, singletonPackages);
  }

  const container = await loadMFERemoteEntry(name);

  // @ts-expect-error Webpack internals
  await container.init(__webpack_share_scopes__[scope.name], undefined, scope.name);

  const initModule = await container.get(".");

  return initModule();
};
```

**What is the expected behavior?**

nil

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**

Dynamic scope generation

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**

Detailed in description

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**

yes
author: jacobp100

comments.body: Because it is expected, and should not be used in this way?
@alexander-akait What's wrong with the approach set out? I don't think we'll be the only ones that want to dynamically create share scopes at runtime
two reacts with different versions?

Yeah, it is possible for our use case. Each MFE gets one HTML element - and can use whatever framework it wants to on that element. So each MFE using React basically does `ReactDOM.render(<MFE />, element)`.

The MFEs server render too, so we need to make sure that if they're using react, they'll hydrate the MFE with the same version of react on the server.

Did the description in the initial post make sense for the issue we're having regarding peer dependencies?
We stringy recommend don't do it, there are a lot of side effect which will break your app
still can break, better solve it on own side
Out of interest, what do you expect could break? (Assuming the user is using the API correctly)
Closing in favour of #13834 (listed as bug report rather than feature request)

title: splitChunks: new `issuer` option for `cacheGroups`
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

I need separate some polyfills and vendor chunk by new option -- `splitChunks.cacheGroups.{cacheGroup}.issuer`.

## Feature request

And i try write code, using undocumented field `module.resourceResolveData`. This work well only first build. 
But second build (with cache enabled) `module.resourceResolveData` already empty.

This code is not a bug report, but just an example:
```js

const corejsDir = path.dirname(require.resolve('core-js'));
const polyfillsDir = path.join(__dirname, 'source/js/polyfills/');
const polyfillsEntry = path.join(__dirname, 'source/js/polyfills.js');

...
splitChunks: {
    cacheGroups: {
        polyfills: {
            chunks: 'initial',
            enforce: true,
            test: ({ resource, resourceResolveData }) => {
                if ((
                    resourceResolveData
                    && resourceResolveData.context
                    && resourceResolveData.context.issuer
                    && resourceResolveData.context.issuer.indexOf(polyfillsDir) === 0
                ) || (
                    resource
                    && (
                        resource.indexOf(corejsDir) === 0
                        || resource.indexOf(polyfillsEntry) === 0
                        || resource.indexOf(polyfillsDir) === 0
                    )
                )) {
                    return true;
                }
                return false;
            },
            name: 'vendor.polyfills',
            priority: 10,
        },
    },
},
...
```
**What is the expected behavior?**
...

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**

I need separate some polyfills and vendor chunk for modern browser build

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**

```js
...
splitChunks: {
    cacheGroups: {
        polyfills: {
            chunks: 'initial',
            enforce: true,
            issuer: /[\\/]source[\\/]js[\\/]polyfills/, // <-- here
            test: /[\\/]node_modules[\\/]/, 
            name: 'vendor.polyfills',
            priority: 10,
        },
    },
},
...
```

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
no
author: dkrnl

comments.body:
You can have multiple `issuers`, also some modules just don't have issuers, relying only on it is not always a good idea. 

But if you really need this your solution is good, I don't think we really need this in core

Ok, thank you!

Can i write bug-report for empty `module.resourceResolveData` (undocumented field) in cached build?
`resourceResolveData` can be empty too, it is expected

title: Bundling for Node and Browser using performance and perf_hooks
author: joezappie

comments.body:
> I'm making a module that I would like to be available in the browser and Node.

You can't use `perf_hooks` in browser. You need to use multi compiler mode and build two versions for `Node.js` and `browser`.

title: TypeError: this.generator.getConcatenationBailoutReason is not a function

title: Way to recognize when initial compilation with lazy plugin has finished.
body:
## Feature request

I have tried the new lazy compilation option and it's awesome!
I am creating a Create-React-App type of app using webpack-dev-middleware and one thing I noticed is that Webpack marks itself as ready (using `done` hook) before the entry point is compiled. This means if I cold start my app and immediately open the browser, I get an empty white page.

It would be nice to have a way to figure out when the initial compilation is done so only then we can open the browser for better DX. Does something like this in form of a hook already exist?

**What is the expected behavior?**
Webpack only changing to a ready state once the webapp can be visited

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
Better developer experience

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**
For example using a hook, or changing when when Webpack calls the 'done' hook. The PR #12553 which could disable lazy importing for certain files also looks promising, because then maybe I could disable it for my entry files.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
no
author: JonnyBurger

comments.body: I don't think you need hook here, you can do it on tool/application side
@alexander-akait Can you tell me how I could implement it on the application side?
You have `__webpack_hash__` so you can check it was changed or not

There are multiple things that you could do about that:

If your application has only a single entrypoint it make sense to disable lazy compilation for entrypoints, because there is no benefit in only compiling it when visited (since you can only visit this entrypoint). We should make this the default when there is only a single entrypoint.

Above thing will also give the the experience that the browser only opens when the page is ready.

Lazy Compilation has the option to create a custom User Interface when lazy compiling via the `experiments.lazyCompilation.client` option. This allows to disable e. g. a spinner and a message in the browser.

Hey there!

This looks very helpful! Thanks @sokra 

> We should make this the default when there is only a single entrypoint.

I was wondering if it is still your intent to do this by default. 
From my tests with `webpack@5.58.1` and the following config
```
  ...
  entry: './src/index.tsx', // single entry point
  experiments: {
    lazyCompilation: true,
  },
```
It doesn't look like `entries=false` is the default yet.

Maybe you will only do this when `lazyCompilation` is no longer experimental but I wanted to confirm so.

Thank you for your time!

title: Allow dynamic imports to be GC'd
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template or we'll close your issue -->

## Feature request

One of the main motivations for code-splitting is to limit the amount of JS that a user needs to use in order to render an app.

In the context of a SPA, this means downloading only the code necessary to render the current page, and to then dynamically import additional chunks to render other pages to which the user navigates.

Currently, references to resolved dynamic imports seem to be preserved in a global variable, `webpackChunkapp`, preventing them from being GC'd.

<!-- Issues that contain questions or support requests will be closed. -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->
<!-- Check if this feature needs to be implemented in a plugin or loader instead -->
<!-- If yes: file the issue on the plugin/loader repo -->
<!-- Features related to the development server should be filed on this repo instead -->

**What is the expected behavior?**
When dynamically importing a module, do not save references to it in any global variables. Alternatively, if this is not possible, you could allow a method to "unregister" a module.

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
To allow the user's device to GC unused imports, releasing occupied JS heap space on large, code-split apps.

Properly configured, hashed filenames and cache-control directives for assets can prevent unnecessarily re-downloading assets, but still allow devices to GC dynamic imports that aren't in use.

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**
Global references to dynamically imported modules should be destroyed once the import is complete and subscribers to the success / error events have been called.

If this is a breaking change or off-spec for dynamic imports (I haven't looked into the spec in detail), I imagine this being an opt-in feature could potentially work.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
This feels like a very core change that I currently lack the context to complete, but if required I might be able.
author: jnields

comments.body:
> Global references to dynamically imported modules should be destroyed once the import is complete

That should imho be a hard disagree. That violates the semantics of both a CJS require _and_ a dynamic ES import, which both have import-once semantics. I.e. no matter when the module is requested, it will only be actually loaded _once_ and all resolves get handed the same module instance. Opt-in or not, it's a bad idea.

Better to encode _very_ situational behavior like this into a loader/plugin and let Webpack facilitate such a loader/plugin by offering the infrastructural tools to load/delete an existing module reference using e.g. vendor-specific `__webpack__*` prefixed variables or even hooks into formal code generation templates.

Could maybe also expose it as a vendor extension onto `require` or `import` for _weak resolves_.
E.g.

```js
const other = require.weak("./other");
```
```js
const other = await import.meta.weak( "./other" );
```

title: Require and parse webpack bundles
body:
**I'm submitting a feature request**

I have several internal libraries which I want to bundle separately. Some of them are 5/6 years old. Now, let's imagine I have a main product which includes those libraries (already bundled). 

I tried to do so, but when the libraries are bundled the require statements are transformed to something like __webpack_require(n) which results in this: 't.exports = image.hash.gif'. 

When compiling the main product (which requires those bundles), webpack does not parse/resolve the 't.exports = image.hash.gif' and therefore, those assets are not consider for the main product bundle. The only solution I see is to transform the assets of the libraries to base64 so that they end up embedded in the code.

Imo, webpack should be capable of parsing those **webpack__require** and spit another bundle without ignoring the assets referenced on libraries. 

Are you aware of this? Are you planning to support this? Any workaround for now?

If you set up your `loaders` correctly, you almost never need any `!` in any of your requires.

It's unused because you're not using `webpack-dev-server` or `webpack-dev-middleware` with hot reloading enabled. If it was enabled, it'd become `if (true)` instead.

title: Webpack 2.1.0-beta.15 -- Handling circular references
author: wegry

comments.body:
Look at the actual parts that call `__webpack_require__`.

That's a consequence of `export default` -- unlike other exports, `export default` is not hoisted, is not a live binding, and it does not export an identifier, but an expression.

Importing something that was exported with `export default` will take a _copy_ of the export. It's not defined yet, because of the circular dependency, so one of them is going to see `undefined`.

If you want to do a default export while keeping it a live binding, then you could do something like `function doesShow () {}; export { doesShow as default }`. Webpack generates getters in that case[^1], which will always DWIM. Unless you actually read/invoke them at the top level. Then it's up to the nasal demons.

[^1]: something roughly equivalent to `exports = { get default () { return doesShow } }` and replacing `b()` with `importedB.default()`
The semantic of `export default` often confuse people...

Out current webpack.dev.js looks like this: 

> module.exports = {
>     entry: {
>         app: './index.ts',
>         vendor: [
>             'angular', 'angular-ui-router', 'angular-ui-bootstrap', 'angular-sanitize',
>             'bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.css',
>             'ng-draggable',
>             'ag-grid', 'ag-grid/dist/styles/ag-grid.css',
>             'rx/dist/rx.lite.js',
>             'angular-perfect-scrollbar-2',
>             'tinymce'
>             , 'mxClient'
>         ]
>     },
>     output: {
>         filename: 'app.js',
>         path: 'dist/appName'
>     },
>     resolve: {
>         root: __dirname,
>         extensions: ['', '.ts', '.js', '.json'],
>         alias: {
>             tinymce: 'tinymce/tinymce'
>             , mxClient: path.join(__dirname, '../libs/mxClient/js/mxClient.js')
>         }
>     }

And my loader right now looks like this: 
`{
        test: require.resolve(path.join(__dirname, '../libs/mxClient/js/mxClient.js')),
        loaders: [
            'imports?mxBasePath=>"./appName/libs/mxClient", mxLoadStylesheets=>false, mxLoadResources=>false',
            'exports?MedianCellSorter,mxAbstractCanvas2D,mxActor,....'
        ]
    }`
There are like at least 60 more globals i'm trying to export from mxClient.

So my first question is that, is there a better way to load all of these without using a scripts loader?

We'd like to use the the import/require to import the module where necessary, but using the scripts loader will just load it as soon as the app is loaded.

The second problem is that with what i have above, I can only use the module when i do something like this: 
`let mxClientTest: any = require("mxClient");`
and access them through this variable. 
What would be the ideal case, is if I could just call `import "mxClient"` and it'll get added into the global context of my app, so i can just use the mx variables directly without going through a variable.

Anyone know how I can achieve this?
author: awong91

comments.body: Can you re-open at Stack Overflow for a better response? Thanks.

title: Sourcemaps created also included @Angular2, rxjs, etc maps
body:
Hi All

I am working in a @angular2 project so I am creating bundles for it and also sourcemaps but maps are huge for the app that I am creating so i think libs maps are also being included.

any idea how to exclude everything from node_modules ?
author: acostaf

comments.body:
Hi @acostaf adding the exclude property in your config should work.

```
{
        test: /\.js$/,
        loader: 'source-map-loader',
        exclude: 'node_modules'
}
```

title: Cannot resolve module
author: applemate

comments.body:
In your webpack config I think you need to specify the full path

```
path.resolve(__dirname, 'app')
```

You would need to modify your imports to

```
import Header from 'components/Header'
import 'sass/home.scss'
```

Or could also just use relative paths

```
import Header from './Header'
import '../sass/home.scss'
```
Closing given a solution was presented. Feel free to re-open at Stack Overflow.

title: How to pass backend variable to Webpack module?
author: lexkrstn

comments.body:
With `output.library = "Entry"` you can do this:

``` js
<script src="bundle.js"></script>
<script>
var entry = new Entry({
  ... // <--- PHP-generated parameters here
});
</script>
```

---

For security reasons I recommend to avoid inline scripts and read the PHP data from the bundle itself:

``` js
<script type="text/data" id="server-data">
  ... // <--- PHP-generated parameters here
</script>
<script src="bundle.js"></script>
```

@sokra Thank you so much for this hint! Today I'm trying to learn Webpack, and I'm seeing your comment almost a year after you wrote it. I've spent hours trying to figure out how bundle.js could read from `

> For security reasons I recommend to avoid inline scripts

@sokra What are the security concerns of using inline scripts to pass data?

Using something like:
```html
<script>
entry.init({ params });
</script>
```

seems much more explicit and controlled then:
```html
<script id="init-params">{ params }</script>
```
and having this specific element found by id inside of bundled module, data parsed, etc.

Are there any webpack docs that explain it in a bit more detail?
Looking for the same... Searching on the web I can't find nothing as well!
@sokra any update on this thread?

title: Visual Studio Debugging DataTips
body: After many hours, I have got debugging working with Visual Studio and Typescript, but datatips do not work. The reason for this is that Visual Studio thinks that the source is not the true source so is in "dynamic mode". Because of this many debugging capabilities are lost.  But for some odd reason webpack appends *\* WEBPACK FOOTER *\* to the source map. I hacked the source map by hand and removed this and it all worked perfectly. Why is this footer there? is it necessary? Is it possible to switch off?
author: liamcarter111

comments.body: Can you re-open at Stack Overflow? I hope you get a good response there. Thanks.

Hi Guys

At this time I am using "typescript": "2.0.3" and "webpack": "2.1.0-beta.24" 

I found a fix for this, so in order to stop the whole ... // WEBPACK FOOTER // // ./~/tslint-loader! .... which breaks Visual studio 2015 debugging, you have to set noSources: true for your SourceMapDevToolPlugin

```
plugins: [
    ....
    new webpack.SourceMapDevToolPlugin({
        filename: '[file].map', noSources: true,
        include: ['commonBundle.js', 'adminBundle.js', 'tradeReportingBundle.js']
    })
    ....
]
```
It yet adds 4 empty lines in the end of file :-(

title: Trying to use mongoose in nodejs app using Webpack as module Bundler
body:
I am trying to integrate mongoDB in my nodejs-react application. I'm using mongoose as orm.
It started with the folowing errors

```
WARNING in ./~/mongoose/~/mongodb/~/mongodb-core/~/bson/~/bson-ext/ext/index.js
Module not found: Error: Cannot resolve 'file' or 'directory' ./win32/x64/bson in /Users/Johannes/Documents/Development/holmes/node_modules/mongoose/node_modules/mongodb/node_modules/mongodb-core/node_modules/bson/node_modules/bson-ext/ext

```

I came across as similar question on stackoverflow but no luck there. However I have mede the following changes in my webpack config file.

Added node and json loader.

```
{ test: /.json$/, loader: 'json-loader' },

{ test: /.node$/, loader: 'node-loader' }

```

Added resolve and node object.

```
resolve: {


extensions: [ '', '.js', '.json', '.jsx', '.es6', '.babel', '.node'],

modulesDirectories: [ 'node_modules', 'app' ] },

node: {

console: true,

fs: 'empty',

net: 'empty',

tls: 'empty' },

```

`npm install json-loader 
`
`npm install node-loader
`
Here's how my webpack config file looks like now.

```
var path = require('path')
var webpack = require('webpack')
var autoprefixer = require('autoprefixer')
var ExtractTextPlugin = require('extract-text-webpack-plugin')

  entry: [
    'webpack-hot-middleware/client',
    './src/index'
  ],
  target: 'node-webkit',
  output: {
    path: absolutePath,
    filename: 'bundle.js',
    publicPath: assetPath
  },
  plugins: [
    new webpack.optimize.OccurenceOrderPlugin(),
    new webpack.HotModuleReplacementPlugin(),
    new webpack.NoErrorsPlugin(),
    new ExtractTextPlugin("bundle.css")
  ],
  module: {
    loaders: [
      {
        test: /\.js$/,
        loaders: [ 'babel' ],
        exclude: /node_modules/,
        include: path.join(__dirname, 'src')
      },
      // fonts and svg
      { test: /\.woff(\?v=\d+\.\d+\.\d+)?$/, loader: "url?limit=10000&mimetype=application/font-woff" },
      { test: /\.woff2(\?v=\d+\.\d+\.\d+)?$/, loader: "url?limit=10000&mimetype=application/font-woff" },
      { test: /\.ttf(\?v=\d+\.\d+\.\d+)?$/, loader: "url?limit=10000&mimetype=application/octet-stream" },
      { test: /\.eot(\?v=\d+\.\d+\.\d+)?$/, loader: "file" },
      { test: /\.svg(\?v=\d+\.\d+\.\d+)?$/, loader: "url?limit=10000&mimetype=image/svg+xml" },
      {
        // images
        test: /\.(ico|jpe?g|png|gif)$/,
        loader: "file"
      },
      {
        // for some modules like foundation
        test: /\.scss$/,
        exclude: [/node_modules/], // sassLoader will include node_modules explicitly
        loader: ExtractTextPlugin.extract("style", "css!postcss!sass?outputStyle=expanded")
      },
      {
        test: /\.css$/,
        loader: ExtractTextPlugin.extract("style", "css!postcss")
      },
      { test: /\.json$/, loader: 'json-loader' },
      {
                test: /\.node$/,
                loader: 'node-loader'
      }
    ]
  },
  resolve: {
      extensions: [ '', '.js', '.json', '.jsx', '.es6', '.babel', '.node'],
      modulesDirectories: [ 'node_modules', 'app' ]
  },
  node: {
    console: true,
    fs: 'empty',
    net: 'empty',
    tls: 'empty'
  },
  postcss: function(webpack) {
    return [
      autoprefixer({browsers: ['last 2 versions', 'ie >= 9', 'and_chr >= 2.3']})
    ]
  },
  sassLoader: {
    includePaths: [path.resolve(__dirname, "node_modules")]
  }
}

```

title: webpack: how to ordering dependencies between entries
author: Trispa

comments.body:
Just put `<script src="lib.js"/>` before `<script src="app.js" />` in your page...
Browser loads scripts in order synchronously. 
It is more complicated when you bundle multiple entries in one file, I noticed it sometimes does mangle the order. The best solution in this case is to just have your main application as an entry, and from there just `require` or `import` your library.
thanks @megakoresh  i did that and it work well now

author: maiopirata

comments.body:
If you need more control per entry, consider using the multicompiler mode. You would end up with something like this:

``` javascript
module.exports = [{...}, {...}]; // configuration per entry
```

You can configure it per entry this way.

Feel free to re-open at Stack Overflow if that doesn't do the trick.

title: vendors.js: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'apply' of undefined while using webpack
author: ghost

comments.body:
It's better to use `CommonsChunkPlugin` only for your production configuration. Please don't mix it with `HotModuleReplacementPlugin` as that's bound to lead to problems.

If it's still problematic after that change, please re-open at Stack Overflow.

Hey @bebraw , I ran into this problem as well (also using CommonsChunkPlugin).

In my case, I was relying on CommonsChunkPlugin to factor out common libraries (ie jQuery) that might have been relied on in multiple files (that were each included in my page). By removing CommonsChunkPlugin, it resulted in two jQuerys being loaded into the page and sometimes causing subtle interactions with each other.

I assume the correct fix is "you should only import one script per page, and only import a second (CommonsChunk) script if you're running in production".

Seems a bit limiting (and not sure it was documented as such, so thanks for responding on this thread). But if this is the hoop I need to jump through for hot reloading, then I'll do it... :P
And if these are incompatible, can/should there be some sort of check in webpack or a plugin, to error-out when these two plugins coexist?
@mikelambert I would need a concrete example to study to say anything more. Could you open a question at Stack Overflow and link to that?

I also had this issue when forgot to add 'new' before webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin (...)
**before**:          `webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin (...)`
**after**:     `new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin (...)`

title: Inconsistencies within DefinePlugin output
author: alexindigo

comments.body:
It doesn't make sense to define `typeof window` to `true`. `typeof` always returns a string.

It's correct that `isServer` is not replaced. It's not used a "free variable" (because of the `var isServer`). Only free variables are replaced.

@sokra I just experimented to see how replacement works, and this inconsistency stroke me as the odd one.

And by free variable, do you global ones, or not explicitly defined in the current context or something else? Is there a doc I can read more about free variables?

Giving existing example what would the best way (within webpack universe) to get that `if (isServer) {` branches to be removed from the bundle?

Thank you.

> And by free variable, do you global ones, or not explicitly defined in the current context or something else? Is there a doc I can read more about free variables?

Free as in not global, local, or anything. If the free variables were not replaced, the code would crash (one way to put it).

> Giving existing example what would the best way (within webpack universe) to get that if (isServer) { branches to be removed from the bundle?

I would do `if (env === 'SERVER')` or similar (could be `process.env` too if you like that convention).

Feel free to re-open at Stack Overflow for more answers.

title: Question - can a Webpack project import another Webpack library.
body:
Hey there,

Simple question - what's the best way for a Webpack project to depend on another Webpack project?

Are there any caveats we need to be aware of?

So far I have configured a Webpack build to create a dist/bundle.js file - but how does Webpack manage dependencies which have been packed into a single dist/bundle.js file by another version of Webpack?

We currently have dependent NPM packages which are built using Browserify - can we convert these to Webpack relatively easily?

Thanks!
author: davewthompson

comments.body:
I would recommend building that other project using your existing WebPack setup, rather than trying to import the bundle. Could have various issues trying to import an already bundled file, but I don't really know.

You should be able to use any npm package with Webpack just by using `require('the-package');` or `import * as Something from 'package'` (ES6)
Great - thanks @Someguy123 - I'll try that.

I have a similar situation; where I need an already WebPack bundled project (Core) into another WebPack project (App). I don't see a cleaner way to do this. 

The only way I could get the Core to work with App is by exposing it as a global (window.) variable, which I'm not inclined to do. I've tried DLL, Library approaches - both works as long as the source (Core) is exported as Var, when exported as AMD, at runtime, there is an expectation that an AMD module loader must be available, something like RequireJS to handle define.

Perhaps, I'm overcomplicating. Any pointers?

Set `module` field at package.json. webpack 2 can pick that up making it possible to consume other webpack projects.

Feel free to re-open at Stack Overflow more ideas.

title: Force re-compile of file from loader
body:
I have file A that requires a file B. When compiling file A I either know about B in advance or I know there might possibly exists file B in future (without knowing its path so I can't use dependency system). When A doesn't know B, it emits error. When I come across valid file B (in loader), I need to recompile A to reflect dependency on discovered B.

Is there a way to force re-compile of A when I discover file B without setting anything in advance? It can even be some internal API that Watcher uses to emit changes. I did go through source code, but wasn't able to find my answer.

Fyi, I'm finishing goog-loader for Google Closure Library with advanced compilation for production. I have a good enough version, but recovery of invalid dependency without editing file A would be nice.

Thank you.
author: aleskafka

comments.body:
Allow me one more question with possible solution. I just need to know some edgy implementation details I could take advantage of.

How does async callback and emitWarning/emitError works? Does emitted warning cancel pending callback or not? Documentation provides no clue about this behaviour.

When I find that A is missing required file B, can I emitWarning and store pending callback for latter when I discover file B?

You could add a context dependency, which is a dependency to a whole directory. Is this enough for your use case?

If not you can flag the file as not cacheable and call `invalidate` on the watcher.

> When I find that A is missing required file B, can I emitWarning and store pending callback for latter when I discover file B?

no. compilation will not finish until callback is invoked.

Thank you. Yes, context dependency could be solution. I'd imagine it could expect glob pattern as argument, but even dirname is fine. I did notice this method exists, but not that it works with directories.

Allow me two follow-up questions.

How does file dependency works? Say I have file A dependent on B and file B dependent on C. Only file C is changed. Which files are recompiled?

How much overhead is there when I addContextDependency for all application files, but in 99% cases callback is provided with cached source from previous compilation (because there wasn't change that would force re-compilation of those files). Is webpack internally optimized when same source is provided to callback? Or is overhead minimum?

Thank you for your time.

> Say I have file A dependent on B and file B dependent on C. Only file C is changed.

It really A' depends on A and B, B' depends on B and C. Where A' and B' are the generated files from A and B. So when C changes only B' is recomplied.

> Is webpack internally optimized when same source is provided to callback?

yes, if it results in the same hash it is not threaded as changed module.

Thank you for your support. I can finalize goog-loader now, thanks to your input. If it stops acting weird on wrong namespace detection (with automatic revival of all files), I will release it for community.

title: Why does Webpack include in an output bundle variables that are not used in entry chunks?
author: wzup

comments.body:
Dead code stripping is incredibly hard in JavaScript. Take a google trip, youll find out why very, very fast.

Tree-Shaking can strip unused stuff dependant on imports/exportsâ€¦but not variables, as far as I know.

`UglifyJS` easily throws warnings that the variable is not used and doesn't include it in mangled output. And it is even configurable, though I don't remember for sure. So it is possible. 

I was just unexpected to me when I started digging why my app with Webpack's bundles loads slow on mobile, that Webpack doesn't remove unused stuff by default.
As long as you are using ES6 modules, webpack 2 can do this type of work for you.

title: Re-usable JS artifact that can be used with different variables
body:
Dear all,

This is a question on how to build / compile some Javascript modules into an entrypoint **once** and then be able to re-use the output in different environments, with potentially different configurations in each one.

A quick search on ways to pass variables into modules produces:
1. the webpack DefinePlugin
2. aliasing an environment-specific configuration module to have a fixed name in the Javascript code

However both of the above require that the configurations are known in advance and in order to be changed the whole entrypoint needs to be re-compiled.

Is there a way around this?

I'm wondering whether to look into the direction of DllPlugin and DllReferencePlugin, but I'd like to hear some more input on this in case I'm missing something simpler.

End-goal: I want to end up with a Docker container that houses a compiled version of the app and can be given different variables to run with, but not have to be recompiled.

Thanks in advance!

Yannis
author: yannispanousis

comments.body:
> the webpack DefinePlugin

use a runtime variable here instead.

> aliasing an environment-specific configuration module to have a fixed name in the Javascript code

use a switch here instead.

Hi @sokra thanks for your reply!

both your suggestions sound like exactly what I need, but

re DefinePlugin: I can't see a `runtime` option on the DefinePlugin parameters or something similar. How can I achieve a runtime variable?

re aliasing configuration module: that also sounds like what I need but given a compiled JS entrypoint I don't know how to abstract that concept. Are we assuming the use of the DllPlugin?

EDIT: If you literally mean use a `switch` statement then my issue there is that I don't know in advance the possible configurations that I'm going to want, therefore I can't bundle them all up in advance.

title: Code splitting and chunks inter-dependency
body:
Hi, I'd like to inform webpack that a lazily loaded chunk should depend on another to save some downloading and I think it's not currently possible.

There are basically two kind of users we support, clients and internal users. The internal users are able to use the client's features but additional features are supported for them. So, I'd like to lazily load some code for both clients and internals, but in the case of internal users, when they would require the advanced features, I'd like to instruct the system to only load the additional code, which is much smaller than the full chunk it currently generates, which is pretty similar to the other chunk for view-mode which is the only one enabled for clients. Here's some example to illustrate

viewer.js
require('./base.js')
// some code for the view mode

edit.js
require('./base.js')
// some code for the edit mode

Usually the edit mode would be launched after the view mode is active. Currently it will redownload 'base.js' and any other common dependencies which are not in the entry JS, while it would be much better if it could require 'viewer.js' if it's not yet loaded and then only load the code which is not shared by viewer.js. So, edit.js would contain some require.ensure(['./viewer.js']) before running the code. Additionally, when generating the edit.js chunk it would assume all modules required by viewer.js are already available.

Please let me know if I wasn't able to express myself very clearly.
author: rosenfeld

comments.body:
I hope I understand you correctly. 

An on-demand chunk doesn't include modules of the parent chunk, as they are already available. If you require.ensure `viewer.js` from `edit.js`, `base.js` would only be in the edit-chunk and not in the viewer-chunk

This is a bit tricky. What you are proposing is to write edit.js like this:

``` javascript
require(['./viewer.js'], function() {
  require('./base.js')
  window.Edit = function(){...}
})

// then it would be called like this:

require(['feature/edit.js'], function(){console.log(window.Edit)}) // obviously it would undefined in the first call
```

One problem is that the call back will be called before edit.js actual code was processed. I have to add some setTimeout work-around to wait for window.Edit to become available before trying to use it.

Is there API I could call in some module to notify when it's considered loaded?

Another problem is that it was creating 2 chunks in the original example containing the View code. I had to use require.ensure and provide it a name in both places requiring 'viewer.js', so that webpack could understand that code should belong to the same chunk.

Also, from a design point of view, edit.js do not really depend on viewer.js. It only depends on base.js, but for performance optimization I prefer to bundle base and viewer in the same chunk and make the edit.js chunk depend on the view.js chunk because I think that makes sense due to how those codes are used in our application.

It would be awesome if webpack could provide me some means to specify such chunks dependencies and actually only run the handler once the parent chunk has been completely evaluated rather than running just after requesting the child chunk.

Please let me know if this explanation is confusing.
@rosenfeld Did you manage to figure this out?

To these days I'm still running a setTimeout and checking whether or not Edit is available every 10 ms. Something like this:

```CoffeeScript
    lazyRun = =>
      (setTimeout lazyRun, 10; return) unless window?.Edit # the actual name is a bit different
      @_runActualThing()
    require.ensure ['transactions/edit.js.coffee'],
      (-> require ['transactions/edit.js.coffee'], lazyRun), 'transaction-edit'
```

title: Split modules bundled via context into separate chunks
body:
Considering I have the following context requirement in my application:

```
// entry.js
const reqFixtures = require.context('./components', true, /^\.\/.*\-fixture\.js$/);
```

Is there anyway, with existing plugins/features, I could tell webpack to split the output into a chunk per file found within the above context?

If my tree looks like:

```
- components/
  - button/
    - button-fixture.js
  - input/
    - input-fixture.js

```

in the case above I'd end up with chunks:

```
- button-fixture.js
- input-fixture.js
- entry.js
```

My use case is having a large test/playground application which can reference tens of fixtures with hundreds of components. I don't want to load all that if we only want to look at a single fixture for a single component, I'd much rather lazy load on demand.

---

If there are no existing mechanisms or plugins to achieve this it'd be great to have some pointers on how to approach a plugin to do this? I was thinking we could look at the emitted modules and if the module path matches against the same expression as the context used then we could pull that module out into a new chunk. That bit seems like it might be relatively trivial but then how to handle pulling dependencies of those matching modules into the chunks? Or would this be handled by `DedupePlugin`?

Anyway, thanks in advance and sorry if this has been discussed before!
author: chrisui

comments.body:
for webpack 1 you can use the `bundle-loader` or the `promise-loader`: `require.context("bundle!./components", ...)`

for webpack 2 it's the default behavior for `System.import("./components/" + ...)`

Didn't even think of using loaders in context! I'll give this a try later.

Thanks!

title: I have a question __dirname setting of node config
body:
Hi there.

I'm using express with webpack.
I found __dirname needs set for node and i set like below

```
node: {
  __dirname: false
}
```

Docs comment `__dirname: true` is real __dirname, but Above works. Not `true` (true output '')
Is Docs correct, or not ?

thanks about greate tool!
author: blackpost38

comments.body:
`__dirname: false` disables webpack processing of `__dirname`. If you run the bundle in node.js it falls back to the __dirname of node.js (which makes sense for target: node).
`__dirname: true` let webpack replace `__dirname` with the path relative to you `context`. Makes sense for target: web if you need the path.

I just have the same problem. I think that documentation is very unclear about what it will do:

```
__dirname: true (real dirname), "mock" ("/") or false
```

Great answer thanks!
I wish to apply that comment to docs :)
Yeah, this is confusing. The documentation reads as if the boolean values should have the opposite effect in the resulting bundle.

> __dirname: false disables webpack processing of __dirname. If you run the bundle in node.js it falls back to the __dirname of node.js (**which makes sense for target: node**).

@sokra given what you said above re what makes sense, why is webpack unexpectedly breaking node's behaviour? Shouldn't the node options all be *false* automatically if target is *node*? The mangling of __dirname is counter intuitive and without warning. And in most cases, the output built for node will operate incorrectly rather than failing.

title: Why have to install webpack twice
body:
I first install webpack global and I think it should work, but when to run webpack command at the project folder it throw error which said can't find module webpack. 

I read the guide of webpack it recommend to setup webpack as the project dependence. I can't understand why has this design. 

so many known issue I didn't find a similar one so create this.
author: baotongw

comments.body:
You don't have to install it globally.

Local installation is better because every project could have a different webpack version.

sorry response late. for the issue I tried again today that if I only install webpack locally and run the webpack command at the project root it said webpack command is not found, it was searching the command from global package. if I only install it global it throw the error above. so I have to install webpack in two places. 

Is that right, anything I missing? my platform is windows 10 with node 0.10.32.

If you installed it globally then `webpack ./entry.js bundle.js` should work.
Maybe you uninstalled it, and forgot? You can check like this:
`npm list --depth 0 --global webpack | grep webpack`

If you only have it installed locally, then you should execute:
`node_modules/.bin/webpack ./entry.js bundle.js` from you project root. Or you could add it to your package.json scripts like this:

```
"scripts" : {
  "build" : "webpack ./entry.js bundle.js"
}
```

and execute: `npm run build`. This will still run the local version because npm will first look in `./node_modules/.bin/`

This is not so much a webpack issue as an npm feature. It's just the way npm works.

I hope I understood your question and answered it correctly.

thanks for your feekback @devboell, it is clearly from your answer, with either global or local copy I need to run command in specify format, and seems it only compile one file each time not full compile, that may not good for big project which contain many export files.
What I expected is if I install webpack globally, I can run 'webpack' command at the project root folder, then it will read webpack-config.js file and execute full compile logic, in that way I can share the same webpack copy across different projects and make the compile much easy. 
With local copy it just a javascript lib, and need npm command to run each compile, also bring more work I think.

sure, I just used the simplest example from webpack docs. But even in this example it will not just compile entry.js, it will compile every file that is required/imported by entry.js, ie. the entire dependency tree. Of course in a real project you would use webpack.config,js.
  The reason why people recommend using the local copy, has to do with managing versions. And as I said, this is not webpack specific, it is how npm has been designed. It works really well.

  I suggest you read some more on npm and webpack and experiment with it. Good luck.
well, `node_modules/.bin/webpack ./entry.js bundle.js` that stuff is needed in the documentation where it shows how to use webpack globally but says we should only install it locally.

> and seems it only compile one file each time not full compile, that may not good for big project which contain many export files.

That's not entirely true. webpack is a powerful tool but highly depends on how you use it. Lot's of projects are using it to generate a complex website/web app, not just compile one file at a time.

> What I expected is if I install webpack globally, I can run 'webpack' command at the project root folder, then it will read webpack-config.js file and execute full compile logic, in that way I can share the same webpack copy across different projects and make the compile much easy. 

You probably had it wrong regarding how node.js works. Installing global package is not recommended if you have multiple projects to run. And certainly lots of CLI tools are working as the same way webpack does, reading each individual configuration files per project, not globally. Because each projects are different. If you have similar projects, you can either copy them around or create a git branch to achieve the result.

> With local copy it just a javascript lib, and need npm command to run each compile, also bring more work I think.

webpack **IS** a npm package after all. If that's not what you expect, you probably got it wrong from the beginning.

title: Any Way to Reverse the Order of Require.Context?
body:
In my particular use case, I have a folder structure like this:
- angular
  - directives
    - date-range
      - index.js
    - module.js
- module.js

And id like to simply do

``` javascript
require.context('./angular');
```

Right now it seems to include files in the bundle in child first order. So my directives are getting put in the file before the module definitions. Essentially Id like files higher up in the hierarchy to appear before files deeper in the hierarchy.

Is there anyway to do this with require.context?
author: pixelshaded

comments.body:
For this use case, the module files create the modules. The directive files then add directives to those modules. If those modules aren't run and exist before the directive code is run, things won't work right. These aren't commonjs at the moment. I'm really just using webpack process (es6 babel etc) and concat all the files together.

So I started comparing the output for better understanding, and it seems I totally misunderstood what's going on. I haven't gotten to the point yet of testing the bundle on a page and had assumed that the order in which the modules appeared in output was the order they would be executed (aka a pure concat). WRONG. I didn't realize an array of module functions was being passed to the bootstrapper. This is commonjs for front end. Nothing is run until you require a module. All require.context was doing was setting up the modules. So yes, the order of modules passed to the bootstrapper doesn't matter. The order in which you require those modules does, hence your example of re-ordering the keys based on directory depth and then executing them in that new order.

Thanks for taking the time to answer my question.

title: Can HMR allow entry point modules with exports to be accepted by sibling entry point modules?
body:
I have the following entries setup:

``` js
"entry": {
      "article": [
        "babel-polyfill",
        "router/initializer",
        "views/article.jsx"
      ],
      "articles": [
        "babel-polyfill",
        "router/initializer",
        "views/articles.jsx"
      ],
      "home": [
        "babel-polyfill",
        "router/initializer",
        "views/home.jsx"
      ]
    },
```

So a different entry chunk is generated for each view, and the `router/initializer` module can load arbitrary views by name (using `require.ensure` + contexts). Since the  initializer is always packaged into the same chunk as a particular view, requiring that view (using `require.ensure`) simply resolves immediately - it only every downloads a new chunk when trying to load a different view. This all works fine so far.

The problem is that HMR never considers the "current" view (i.e. the one packaged into that chunk) to be a dependency of anyone (not the initializer, nor the `views/*.jsx` context module). `module.hot.accept(viewsContext.id, ...)` doesn't do anything (nor does `module.hot.accept(viewsContext.resolve('./home.jsx', ...)`. `module.hot.apply({ignoreUnaccepted: true}, ...)` never applies it. Only `module.hot.accept()` in `home.jsx` itself does. I assume this is because HMR only looks as far as "is this module an entry point?" and since it is, assumes there are no exports and it can only accept itself. That's not the case here though - there _are_ exports - and they are used by _another_ entry point module.

Is that what's actually happening, or is something else the problem?

If that is the case, can HMR be made to go through the dependency checking of entry point modules anyway, as long as they have exports?
author: clarabstract

comments.body: Nvm actually...  problem was I shouldn't have set up my entries that way. I keep forgetting entry chunks can't do double duty as dynamically loadable non-entry chunks.

title: Generating dependencies (in `make` style)
body:
I would like to integrate **webpack** in embedded software project, which I build using _GNU Make_. I need the dependencies list like this:

```
client.js: src/client.coffee src/client.less
src/client.coffee: src/module1.coffee src/module2.coffee
src/client.less: src/basic.less src/theme.less
...
```

I.e. I need execute **webpack** from **Makefile** only when one or more dependencies was changed.

Is there a simple way to do it? Or does I need to implement plugin?
author: katyo

comments.body:
Can you describe more indetail what you want? Do you want to have Webpack print which files depend on what? For that to work, you have to run one build, no matter what.

Since I never worked with Make, I will do a blunt assumption:

```
output: dep1 dep2
```

is the style of Make dependencies.

Going by that assumption, you can feed WebPack multiple entry-points. For instance if you configured it with a setting of `output:{ filename: "[name].js" }`, you can use inlined node-js to run webpack:

```
node -e "require('./make-webpack')('$makeInput', $makeOutput);"
```

`$makeInput` would be the space-separated string of your dependencies you want as entries.
`$makeOutput` would be the name of the output. in your `client.js` example, it would be `client`. i THINK if you set `filename: "[name]"` only, then you can even use `client.js` as the entrypoint name.

`make-webpack.js` could look like this (pseudo):

``` javascript
var webpack = require("webpack");
var config = require("./webpack.config");
module.exports = function(deps, name) {
    config.entry = {};
    config.entry[name] = deps.split(" ");
    var compiler = webpack(config);
    compiler.run(SomeCallbackHandler);
}
```

And presto, you made a little tool that you can use underneath Make.

I only know Ninja.. so in Ninja, I would define a rule like so:

``` ninja
rule webpack
  command = node -e 'require("./make-webpack")("$in", "$out")'
  description = WebPack: Making $out of: $in
```

You can also customize the script to utilize `argv` if you prefer, but this is a quick and dirty solution!

I hope this helps. :)

Thanks.

My own solution is a simple plugin, which looks like this (CoffeeScript):

``` CoffeeScript
#
# makedeps-webpack-plugin.coffee
#

{resolve} = require "path"
{writeFile} = require "fs"

class @MakeDepsPlugin
  constructor: ({@output, @target, @depends} = {})->

  apply: (compiler)->
    {output, target, depends} = @
    compiler.plugin "emit", ({fileDependencies, chunks}, done)->
      output ?= "webpack-makedeps.mk"
      target ?= chunks[0]?.files?.join " "
      extraDeps = (resolve dep for dep in depends or [])
      depends = [extraDeps..., fileDependencies...].join " \\\n  "
      writeFile output, "#{target}: \\\n  #{depends}", done
```

For example, this plugin can be used like so (CoffeeScript):

``` CoffeeScript
{MakeDepsPlugin} = require "makedeps-webpack-plugin"

...
  plugins: [
    new MakeDepsPlugin
      output: "depends.mk"
      depends: [
        "package.json"
        "Cakefile"
      ],
      ...
  ]
```

The result is a file _depends.mk_ which contains that:

```
client.js client.css: \
  /home/kayo/project/package.json \
  /home/kayo/project/Cakefile \
  /home/kayo/project/client.coffee \
  /home/kayo/project/client.less \
  /home/kayo/project/bootstrap.js \
  <...>
```

Looks good to me! :)

Anything else you would like to know?
No, thanks. I think, this issue can be closed.

author: pawawat

comments.body:
By not using it.

When you use a context, you usually have something like:

```
"./file/"+aVar+".js"
```

aVar in this case would be the basename for the file. As you see, the path is constructed dynamically. WebPack can not tell what the paths may look like, and your aVar will indeed contain the raw basename. So in order to allow you to build contexts, it needs to lay out the require calls as string.

So there is no way to hide it, unless you donâ€™t use it, iâ€™m afraid.

title: Errors in preLoaders are not caught, breaking build process
body:
I have both `jshint-loader` and `jscs-loader` configured as preLoaders to check my code. If there's a problem, webpack reports the error in lovely red text and exits gracefully. As of yesterday, however, the error is uncaught, which breaks my "watch" process.

Here's what I get if I introduce a missing semicolon error:

```
/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/webpack-core/lib/NormalModuleMixin.js:151
                throw e;
                ^
Error: ModuleError: jshint results in errors
  Missing semicolon. @ line 158 char 31
        }, { normalizeRGB: true }),ModuleBuildError: Module build failed: Error: Module failed in cause of jshint error.
    at Object.jsHint (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/jshint-loader/index.js:127:9)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/jshint-loader/index.js:146:11)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/jshint-loader/index.js:37:12)
    at respond (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/rcloader/index.js:68:7)
    at respond (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/rcfinder/index.js:140:7)
    at next (/Users/brianchirls/www/VR/webpack-vr-template/node_modules/rcfinder/index.js:167:16)
    at doNTCallback0 (node.js:430:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:359:13)
```

I'm pretty sure the problem is not with jscs, jshint or either of their loaders, since I get a similar error if I put the semicolon back and change to mixed tabs/spaces, which bugs jscs but not jshint. And the problem isn't with my own code or configuration, since I still see the same error if I roll my own code back to several days ago. I notice there hasn't been an update to webpack, webpack-core or gulp (which I'm using) in the last couple days, so maybe there's another dependency buried in there somewhere that changed?

title: Use CommonsChunkPlugin twice on one page
body:
As part of our caching strategy, I have set up a configuration where we have two instances of CommonsChunkPlugin: one for vendor scripts; one for common app code. Now we want to include both on every page. But the generated `vendor.js` and `commons.js` each include the webpack runtime, which doesn't work.

Is there a way to remove the runtime from one of those bundles, or is there a different correct way to do this?
author: andrewbranch

comments.body:
I have two instances of CommonsChunkPlugin : vendor and common.
webpack.conf:

```
var entry = {
        profile: [ './app/frontend/javascripts/profile/main.es6'],
        projects: [ './app/frontend/javascripts/projects/main.es6'],
        // the vendor entry point
        vendor: ['babel-polyfill', 'lodash', 'jquery']
    };
```

```
    var plugins = [
        new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin("common", 'common' + (options.longTermCaching ? '-[chunkhash].js' : '.js'), ['projects', 'profile']),
        new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin("vendor", 'vendor' + (options.longTermCaching ? '-[chunkhash].js' : '.js' ), ['common', 'vendor'], Infinity)
    ];
```

The webpack runtime is only present into the vendor bundle and I can use them like this :

```
  <script src="[...]/assets/vendor.js"></script>
  <script src="[...]/assets/common.js"></script>
  <script src="[...]/assets/profile.js"></script>
```

I hope this will help you (I don't know if it is the correct way to do it but it seems to work)

> Is there a way to remove the runtime from one of those bundles, or is there a different correct way to do this?

@andrewbranch You can do it the way @fredericgrati does it. One of the Plugins should have the name of the other commons chunk in the `chunks` property.
I'm a little confused but that seems to work nicely. Thanks!

title: Make TemplatedPathPlugin's replacePathVariables available as a utility.
author: lzilioli

comments.body: Submitted #1649 to address this issue. Feedback welcome, I would love to get this into a release if possible.

You can use it in your plugin.

`TemplatedPathPlugin` is not this thing that does the replacement. It's just a plugin that add some replacements. The actual API is the hook `asset-path` that's usable by everything that has a reference to the mainTemplate (which is in the compilation).

``` js
mainTemplate.applyPluginsWaterfall("asset-path", "some string [hash]", {
    hash: hash,
    chunk: chunk
})
```

If you want to improve something here, add a `getAssetPath(string, options)` function to the `MainTemplate` that calls the hook and replace all occurences. That would look better.

see also #427
cc @diurnalist
@sokra Thanks a lot for the detailed response. This does, in fact meet my needs.
